citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the required Institutional Animal Care & Use Committee paperwork was not available for review
and examination by APHIS officials. The facility representative present today was not able to access the records in their
colleague’s absence. Review of IACUC paperwork ensures the IACUC is functioning as intended to ensure the welfare of
the animals used and housed by the facility. The facility shall ensure that records required by the Animal Welfare Act
(AWA) and the regulations are available for APHIS officials to review on all inspections.
Correct by November 8, 2023.

A total of 7 adult cats are currently housed in primary enclosures that do not meet the required 24-inch heigh requirement.
The resting platform further reduces the vertical space of the enclosure, and two of the cats were observed crouching to
move around in the enclosure. Failure to provide adequate enclosure height (at least twenty-four inches) prevents cats
from making normal postural adjustments and can lead to unnecessary discomfort and distress. Correct by ensuring all
primary enclosures housing cats are at least 24” height.
Correct by October 31, 2023.

The large hoof stock pasture had various areas in disrepair. One housing shelter in a distant paddock had sections of
metal siding no longer attached to its frame, curving away from the structure and creating sharp projections. Additionally,
the shared fence line between two of the large hoof stock pastures had a significant portion of the chain link fence torn
apart, creating a hole with adjacent wire curling up and out. The subsequent exposed edges of the fence line now
exposed sharp points. The exposed metal and sharp points pose a risk of injury to the animals contained therein. The
outdoor facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and
to contain the animals.
Correct by January 1, 2024.

Two separate primary enclosures housing horses and cattle did not have clean drinking water. The area housing three
horses had a water trough containing cloudy, green water. The water trough in the large hoof stock pasture also had
green, discolored water with increased amounts of sediment present. The water was significantly cloudy in both troughs,
with inspectors unable to see through to the bottom of the receptacles. Though the facility stated the horses in the first
enclosure would be turned out the same day, the water receptacles had not been replenished as needed.
The consumption of unclean drinking water can cause severe illness and decline in an animal’s health. Accessibility to
potable water is necessary for the well-being and comfort of the animal. All water receptacles must be kept clean and
sanitary.
Correct by September 12, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
CARLA THOMAS, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
